constellations_other.name: Webwurlds
constellations_other.description: Jess Johnson and Simon Ward's work is inspired by science fiction and fantasy. Johnson's hand-drawn illustrations are heavily detailed with geometric patterns and incorporate anthropomorphic characters amongst architectural environments in immersive other worlds.

results.title: The Lion king
results.creator_credit: Walt Disney Pictures, Don Hahn, Roger Allers and Rob Minkoff
results.brief_description: This beautifully animated and wonderfully scored feature film tells the story of the love between a proud lion ruler, Mufasa, and his son, Simba - a naive and curious cub who must find his place in the “circle of life”. Through the help of his friends, and his determination to meet the toughest challenges, Simba eventually takes his place as the rightful ruler of the Pride Lands. His search to meet his destiny puts him face to face in a struggle to the death with his evil uncle Scar and also leads him towards true love. Elton John and Tim Rice’s award winning songs, an excellent score by Hans Zimmer, and voice characterisations by Jeremy Irons, James Earl Jones, Rowan Atkinson, Robert Guillame, Moira Kelly and Matthew Broderick as Simba, make this an unforgettable experience.

constellations_other.name: The drama and nuance of silhouette
constellations_other.description: Ali Gumillya Baker uses silhouette to evocative effect in her work reimagining the colonial gaze. The lighting technique has long been employed by filmmakers for its ability to dramatically convey a wide variety of emotions in everything from film noir to animation and whimsy.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Walt Disney Pictures, Don Hahn, Roger Allers and Rob Minkoff

results.title: Shadow Play [interactive]
results.brief_description: The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows, which visitors can do at the entrance to The Story of the Moving Image.

constellations_primary.name: Shadow play
constellations_primary.description: Shadow play uses light and projection to tell stories – fundamentals that would evolve into cinematography. In the Wayang tradition, gunungan open and close performances and indicate scene changes and the puppets pass across the projection screen in a similar way to a wipe transition.

results.description:
The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows.

Relive the origins of the moving image by casting your own shadow as it bends, towers and twists to craft imagined worlds, wonderous characters and incredible tales in this interactive experience that unites ancient storytelling techniques with modern technology.
description_for_label:
The discovery of fire not only banished the darkness and provided warmth to our ancestors, it also allowed them to shape their imagination by projecting shadows.

Relive the origins of the moving image by casting your own shadow as it bends, towers and twists to craft imagined worlds, wonderous characters and incredible tales in this interactive experience that unites ancient storytelling techniques with modern technology.

details.label: Curatorial section

results.title: Prisoner
results.creator_credit: Reg Grundy Productions and Marie Trevor
results.brief_description: Created by Reg Watson and screening a total of 692 episodes between 1979 and 1986, “Prisoner” was one of the first television series to tackle issues such as rape, homosexuality and violence. It did this through the relationships between a cross section of women and the women who work around them at the Wentworth Detention Centre. This groundbreaking serial funded by the Grundy Organisation was screened in countries throughout the world and was remade in Germany and the U.K. The complete title of the series overseas was “Prisoner: Cell block H”. PLEASE NOTE: the dates recorded in entries pertain to copyright year and usually preceeds the screening year.

constellations_other.name: Nadia Tass
constellations_other.description: Comedic and cult classics take centre stage in Nadia Tass' career.

This groundbreaking serial, funded by the Grundy Organisation, was screened in countries throughout the world and was remade in Germany and the U.K. The complete title of the series overseas was Prisoner: Cell block H.

results.title: Spawn
results.brief_description:
What do freak-science, fairies and queer flower coding have in common?

These themes intersect in a new experimental video work by Te Whanganui A-Tara based artist Laura Duffy. “Spawn” explores political underpinnings of categorisations of ‘natural’ and ‘unnatural’ in relation to bodies. Exploring critically the process of bodies considered natural or normal.

“Spawn” is an ACMI + CIRCUIT Commission which supports an invited Australasian artist to deliver an experimental new work specifically for an online context.
results.description:
Spawn is a gift to those of us (so many of us!) who have been living through lockdowns. With the unwelcome mantle of ‘most locked-down city in the world’, Melbourne audiences were at the forefront of artist Laura Duffy’s mind when she created Spawn. Duffy mixes materials together like potions, encouraging audiences to consider texture through filmic spaces in which the natural and unnatural writhe upon one another – slipping, dripping, bubbling, congealing.

Responsive to a context of global pandemic mixed in with climate crisis, Duffy is moved by sentiments of kindness and generosity, inviting audiences into the ‘poetic, fun, fresh, flowery, camp and flirty’ world of Spawn

The work reflects Duffy’s belief that materials are collaborative, complete with their own stories, histories and energies. The artist combines these materials to critique and shatter binary thinking of natural and unnatural as separate, instead embracing the complexity and blur of binaries. ‘How are we able to unleash from the constraints of “nature” to find new pleasures? A Post-nature embrace of all that is and will be, even if its toxic?’ Duffy questions.

Spawn is also a work about gratitude. A filmic study of death and transformation. As golden liquid pours over rotting, spinning fruits and flowers, Duffy encourages us to ‘say thank you and rejoice in transformation and transmutation.’

An additional element of the work will be released in January 2022. Conscious that so many of us have been confined to our homes and tied to our screens, Duffy is collaborating with artist and friend Aliyah Winter to create a downloadable audio work that we can walk around with, enjoying at our leisure, wherever we please.

– Serena Bentley, Curator, ACMI
description_for_label:
What do freak-science, fairies and queer flower coding have in common?

These themes intersect in a new experimental video work by Te Whanganui A-Tara based artist Laura Duffy. “Spawn” explores political underpinnings of categorisations of ‘natural’ and ‘unnatural’ in relation to bodies. Exploring critically the process of bodies considered natural or normal.

“Spawn” is an ACMI + CIRCUIT Commission which supports an invited Australasian artist to deliver an experimental new work specifically for an online context.

results.title: head_phone_film_poems
results.brief_description:
head_phone_film_poems is a collection of thirteen films that creatively remix material from online archives including the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) film material in the National Archives of Australia, crime scene photographs from the Justice and Police Museum Sydney, and Gibson’s own social-media-stored collection of strange late-night phenomena filmed in his neighbourhood over the past decade. Drawing on these caches of ‘readymade’ footage, the head_phone_film_poems are shaped by three guiding principles: they must be produced entirely on the iPhone, they must feature some visualised language and they must suggest an enormous amount more than they show.

[Sourced from ACMI website event page https://www.acmi.net.au/whats-on/ross-gibson-head_phone_film_poems/ 9/6/2021]

results.title: Stargate for Game Boy
results.creator_credit: Acclaim Entertainment Ltd and Laser Beam (Beam Software)
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
Ra, the vicious alien ruler of Abydos, is using Stargates find resource-rich worlds to conquer and enslave its inhabitants. Only the player can stop Ra by cracking the Stargates’ codes and closing them before they can be misused. Stargate, while based on the action sci-fi franchise, is a matching puzzle game, similar to Tetris but with a 3D aspect. Tiles are dropped into a Stargate and matching three tiles with the same symbol clears the tiles. The game is lost when too many tiles fill up the space.

Adding complexity is the “address”, a set of seven symbols across the top of the screen that the player must clear by stacking three tiles of that symbol. The game features two modes. Skill Mode has the player clearing addresses before the tiles fill up. The game’s speed increases as more and more addresses are cleared. In Battle Mode, a player can play against the computer or another player via a link cable to another handheld. Clearing stacks adds them to your opponent’s field, hopefully overwhelming them and winning the match.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Acclaim Entertainment Ltd and Laser Beam (Beam Software)

results.title: Reach for the Stars for PC
results.creator_credit: Strategic Simulations, Inc. and Strategic Studies Group
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD case insert, CD jewel case, licence agreement and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Reach for the Stars is a re-released and updated version of the DOS era game of the same name, the earliest example of a game in the 4X genre. The player starts off in a single planetary system and must eventually create and run an interstellar empire. In typical 4X style, this is done by exploring the universe around the player, expanding by claiming new territory, exploiting any resources in the area and exterminating any opponents along the way. The re-release features updated graphics and new scenarios for the player.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Strategic Simulations, Inc. and Strategic Studies Group

results.title: Play It Again II: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again II project aims to document, preserve, and create an accessible and playable history of Australasian videogames and videogame culture from the 1990s.

This collection comprises physical games and hardware donated to ACMI for the project and as well as game emulation files created by ACMI or harvested from external web repositories.

The project is being undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Swinburne University, RMIT, AARNet, UNESCO PERSIST and OpenSLX GmbHt.
This project is supported by the Australian Government through the Australian Research Council Linkage Program. Play It Again II is a continuation of Play It Again I, which focused on the preservation of Australasian videogames from the 1980’s.

production_dates.notes: Games in this Collection date from the 1990s. The ARC research project "Play It Again" (II) will be completed in 2022.

results.title: Nightshade for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve, manual and epilepsy warning sheet in cardboard box
results.brief_description: After Metro City’s local superhero Vortex is killed, the power vacuum leads to a villain named Sutekh taking control of the city’s gangs and enveloping the city in crime. Only one person can stop them: A vigilante named Nightshade. The game is a point-and-click adventure, meaning the player can examine and interact with the environment, talk to the citizens of Metro City and fight Sutekh’s minions. The game boasts a ‘Personality Gauge’ which changes based on the player’s actions. Increased popularity has gameplay implications such as additional information from grateful citizens. Despite the dark setting, the game itself is light in tone and is filled with jokes and pop culture references.
